document_title: Salivary gland inflammation: Symptoms, causes and treatments
subsection_content:
According to pathology, salivary gland infections often occur in 3 main salivary glands:
Parotid salivary gland inflammation: An infection of the salivary glands located on both cheeks, in front of the ears. This is the body's largest salivary gland. Submandibular salivary gland inflammation: Is an infection of the salivary glands located under the jaw. These are the second largest salivary glands. Sublingual salivary gland inflammation: Is an infection of the salivary glands located on both sides of the tongue, under the floor of the mouth. This is the smallest of the major salivary glands.; Parotid salivary gland inflammation: An infection of the salivary glands located on both cheeks, in front of the ears. These are the second largest salivary glands.; Sublingual salivary gland inflammation: Is an infection of the salivary glands located on both sides of the tongue, under the floor of the mouth. This is the smallest of the major salivary glands.
Dr. Thuy Hang added that in addition to these main glands, many small salivary glands are distributed throughout the mouth. All glands that produce saliva and aid in the breakdown of food as part of the digestive process can become inflamed if infected with viruses or bacteria.
